discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
By disabling BGP route propagation on the route table associated with the subnet, the BGP routes advertised from your on-premises network via the VPN connection will not be propagated to this subnet. This means the new subnet will not have a route back to the on-premises network and will therefore be unreachable from the on-premises network.

This is YES if the RT is configured with route propagation disabled on the new subnet.

But NO if the RT is configured with route propagation disabled on the VPNGW subnet

Not enough info to really say YES or NO - I hope this doesn't show up on the exam. :))

B. Object distinguished name - The distinguished name (DN) is a critical piece of information as it uniquely identifies the object in the Active Directory hierarchy. It includes the name of the domain where the object resides, the organizational unit (OU) that contains the object, and the common name (CN) of the object itself.

E. Object globally unique identifier - The globally unique identifier (GUID) is a unique reference number used as an identifier in software. In the context of AD DS, the GUID is a unique value that remains with the object for its entire lifespan, even when the object is moved or renamed.

I think D is wrong because the AD Connector name (Option D) is not usually required when troubleshooting a specific object synchronization issue in Azure AD Connect. Typically, issues with a specific object (like a user or a group) are investigated based on information related to the object itself (like its Distinguished Name or its GUID), rather than the name of the connector.
